topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Cold open on avoiding overly ambitious first startups, then Lenny introduces Andrew Wilkinson, Tiny’s model, and the episode’s major themes (ideas, AI, happiness).

topics.title: Finding startup ideas by avoiding crowded markets
topics.summary: Andrew shares his core idea heuristic: pursue niches with less competition (“fish where the fish are”), contrasting glamorous ideas (cafes) with unsexy but profitable ones (funeral homes, pest control, government forms).

topics.title: Start small to build entrepreneurial “reps”
topics.summary: He argues first-time founders should pick simpler businesses to get early wins and confidence, sharing his own early agency success and later failures when he overreached into unfamiliar models.

topics.title: Avoid building a job: scale and delegation
topics.summary: They discuss how founders accidentally create jobs they hate; Andrew explains that many “dirty work” businesses become attractive once scaled enough to hire operators, emphasizing “lazy leadership” and shedding disliked tasks fast.

topics.title: Choosing software vs physical businesses via unfair advantage
topics.summary: Andrew frames idea selection around personal strengths and distribution advantages, giving examples of adjacent opportunities (restaurant vendors) and how passions can lead to durable, profitable bets (Letterboxd, AeroPress).

topics.title: Judging market value: experience, gut, and AI research
topics.summary: They explore how to tell if a problem is worth solving; Andrew says it’s largely pattern recognition built from experience, but founders can now use LLMs to model unit economics and constraints before committing.

topics.title: Boring businesses and why flashy ideas fail
topics.summary: Andrew recounts losing $10M competing in project management (Flow vs Asana) and argues boring, overlooked problems (like government form automation) can be far more profitable due to weaker competition.

topics.title: Avoiding “graveyard” business models and false confidence
topics.summary: He warns against entering models with repeated historical failures (bars, local news), noting that strong management can’t fix a fundamentally bad business model; they discuss rare exceptions like Instacart/Webvan.

topics.title: Bootstrapping vs venture: goals, competition, and scale
topics.summary: Andrew argues bootstrapped companies can still become huge, and the real difference is willingness to burn capital; they discuss lifestyle success (Things) and why VCs ignore smaller but great businesses.

topics.title: What makes a great business: moats and acquisition criteria
topics.summary: Andrew explains Tiny’s acquisition philosophy: buy businesses that are hard to ruin, change little post-acquisition, and prioritize moats like brand, network effects, and (less ideally) switching costs.

topics.title: Serato acquisition and passion-driven pattern recognition
topics.summary: They cover Tiny’s purchase of Serato and how Andrew’s personal DJ background helped him understand the product’s moat (user base + hardware integration) and evaluate the opportunity quickly.

topics.title: Hiring and people: “no problems, only people problems”
topics.summary: Andrew shares hiring lessons across Tiny’s portfolio: prioritize avoiding toxic personalities, don’t bet on “potential,” and treat the first serious doubt as a firing signal—especially for leadership roles.

topics.title: Hiring CEOs: alignment, autonomy, and the ‘hammer’ problem
topics.summary: He explains why CEOs tend to execute their own playbook regardless of guidance; Tiny looks for leaders whose instincts match the needed strategy, then gives them space to run without interference.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Miro’s Innovation Workspace and how teams can use AI in collaborative workflows.

topics.title: AI workflows with Lindy: automating email and calendar
topics.summary: Andrew details his AI stack centered on Lindy agents that triage, label, and draft replies to emails, plus calendar automation (including rules and even emoji labeling), effectively replacing assistant-like tasks.
